I predicted this that would happen“ Rose MuletThis is literally just Tidal, but instead of being a spotify clone that’s main selling feature is paying creators more, it’s a YouTube clone that's main selling point is paying creators more. I feel like no one really learned from the failure of Tidal.This app is gonna fail miserably, let’s be honest with ourselves. The views on these videos are all terrible compared to what they get on YouTube, and yes I’m aware the app is just starting out, but with as much exposure as it’s getting, for these big creators to only be a few hundred views, and considering that this probably the most exposure the app will ever get, it’s not looking sustainable.The creators of StoryFire made a huge mistake by marketing themselves to video creators instead of marketing to audiences. Yes they’ll get big names to join their platform, but it won’t mean much if nobody’s logging onto their app. Audiences aren’t going to switch to a worse version of youtube just so their favorite content creators can get a bigger paycheck, they just want to see content in a way that’s easily assessable, and you’ve got to market yourself in a way that offers something to viewers that youtube doesn’t. “What about exclusive videos from their favorite creators?” Tidal tried that already and it didn’t work because as soon as they heard Kanye West & Beyoncé’s new albums, they went right back to spotify and Apple Music. The audiences didn’t have any incentive to stay with tidal, and they preferred the other streaming services.Despite all of its flaws, YouTube is an amazing platform for the viewer, there’s nothing that StoryFire offers that youtube doesn’t already do 10 times better. You could argue the “twitter like features” But youtube already has comments and the community tab which fulfill essentially  the same needs. Given the choice of storyfire or youtube, over 99% of viewers are gonna watch on YouTube, because it’s simply a better platform for the consumer (audience members/video watchers) and creators are eventually gonna realize that they need to stop putting so much effort into a platform very few people outside of content creators themselves actually care about.I think you all are falling into this delusion that this’ll be successful simply because you because you’re sick of all of YouTube’s issues with demonetization (and rightfully so) which means you’re desperate to find any kind of alternative that doesn’t have those issues.Overall, it’s gonna be a nice lil fad that fades out in a few months. I get that you want it to succeed though but lbr, just like Byte it’s gonna be forgotten about real soon.All I’m saying is don’t be surprised when the same commentary channels that are currently promoting the app make videos called “The Failure of StoryFire” in just a few months time...”6 months agoVideo the comments is from: Is this the next YouTube? by John Swanling

I'm positive that most, if not all of these artists don't have permission to draw Belle and post it publicly. That's most definitely a form of advertisement as well, whether intentional or not, meaning the argument could be made that her likeness was used in some way to give the artists attention from the Belle Delphine community, and thus one or several of those fans are most likely going to give the artist money in return, meaning some level of profit was inadvertently made off of her likeness without her permission anyway. It's a bit of a stretch, and I could be wrong somehow as I'm pretty sure fanart is legal, but I don't think what these artists are doing is okay either. You should at least ask somebody before drawing their likeness or property, whether fanart or not. That goes for parodies as well. It's highly recommended by any lawyer or law expert that you ask for permission from the owner of the property you're parodying before you parody it. The Green Med's Stand on mandatory vaccines:    • With round-the-clock media coverage of coronavirus, there is a strong and growing push for Americans to widely accept the impending COVID-19 vaccine — even though the vaccine is experimental and has known safety concerns. However, the U.S. public is currently divided over whether to get the vaccine. In the latest poll from the Pew Research Center, which surveyed more than 10,000 U.S. adults in September, about half of respondents (51%) said they would definitely or probably get a coronavirus vaccine if it were available today.     • Amidst intense public pressure from government and community leaders, there are many people asking, “Will I be forced to get the COVID-19 vaccine?” There are myriad reasons why someone might choose to decline the vaccine. Among the most common are conscientious objections, religious convictions, a history of prior vaccine injury and concerns over safety, including the speed with which the vaccine is being developed and the lack of long-term safety data.     • States across the country have drafted COVID-19 vaccination plans that utilize tracking systems, outline incentives to ensure maximum uptake of the vaccine, and identify priority populations to receive the vaccine. A July 2020 Johns Hopkins report urges local and state public health agencies to explore bundling vaccination with other safety net services. “Bundling services (e.g., food security, rent assistance, free clinic services) that are already being provided to particularly vulnerable populations in the context of COVID (e.g., older adults, low-income adults, Black and minority communities) could be a way to build trust and streamline vaccine provision,” the report says.     • Such programs could ultimately result in the denial of crucial services for those who choose to opt out of the vaccine, thereby stripping individuals of any opportunity to make this medical decision for themselves. Even if the COVID-19 vaccine is not mandated, some states could choose to limit the privileges of those who can’t supply proof of vaccination. This, experts say, is a violation of human rights and constitutional rights — especially since much of the population is not at risk from harm from COVID but could easily experience harm from a fast-tracked, experimental vaccine.     • Under U.S. Supreme Court law, in order to mandate a medical intervention there must be an epidemic that imperils the entire population. According to the CDC’s own data, most people have greater than a 97 percent chance of surviving COVID. In fact, for those under 70, the survivability rate among those infected ranges from 99.5 percent to 99.9 percent. Moreover, the COVID-19 vaccine is not supposed to prevent transmission; it’s merely supposed to lessen symptoms. As such, there is no basis upon which to require the vaccine; it’s up to each person to decide how to care for their own body based on their own judgment and unique physiology.     • It is unethical and immoral to mandate an experimental vaccine that has known safety concerns and for which there is no liability. Under the PREP Act — which was passed in 2005 and invoked in March of 2020 — vaccine and drug manufacturers, government agencies, doctors and all others are 100 percent free from any and all liability (absent intentional wrongdoing) resulting from harm caused by the coronavirus vaccine. Thus, no one will bear responsibility if you or your family is harmed by the vaccine. Lastly, for those with deeply held religious beliefs (or who lead a pharmaceutical-free life), vaccination violates their convictions to abide by natural law and to walk in faith, not fear.     • Stand up for your basic human right for informed consent and to decline a medical intervention! Click below to email and tweet your governor and local lawmakers to urge them to make the COVID-19 vaccine voluntary, not mandatory. Let them know that the only one who stands to profit from the COVID-19 vaccine is the pharmaceutical industry.
